trial_identification.studytitle: The Australian Ultraviolet Radiation and Immunity Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Assessing in healthy young Australian adults whether exposure to solar ultraviolet radiation (UVR) at levels relevant to normal daily activities affects immune response to primary vaccination.

conditions.healthcondition: Impact of solar ultraviolet radiation on human primary immune response to immunisation with a T-cell dependent antigen (Keyhole Limpet Hemocyanin or KLH)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal development and function of the immune system

interventions.interventions: Participants will wear a ultraviolet radiation (UVR) absorbant wrist band which will measure UVR personal exposure for 5 days. Subsequently all participants will be vaccinated subcutaneously with 125mcg keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLH) administered to a sun exposed part of the forearm. Participants will be recruited over a 52 week period.
interventions.comparator: We are correlating UVR exposure against immune response to vaccination. There is not control group.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Humoral response to primary subcutaneous vaccination with Keyhole Limpet Hemocyanin (KLH). KLH-specific immunoglobulins (Ig) (Ig types M, E, G and subsets) will be quantified via enzyme linked immunoassay techniques.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: KLH specific antibody titres taken at baseline (immediately prior to vaccination which follows the 5 days of UVR exposure measurement); 1 week and 3 weeks post vaccination

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) response to intra-dermal KLH will be measured in millimetres of skin reaction
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Intradermal KLH given at day 21 post vaccination. DTH response read at 48 hours post intradermal KLH.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: KLH specific T-cell response will be measured via lymphocyte proliferation assays and cytokine production.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline (immediately prior to vaccination) and day 21.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: * Age 18 - 40 years * Healthy * Willing and able to sign informed consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: * Allergy to shellfish * Pregnancy or breastfeeding * Previous KLH vaccination * Immunosuppressive medications * Immunosuppressive medical condition * Recent infection (within 2 weeks of vaccination) * Recent immunisation with any other vaccine in past 4 weeks * Photosensitive skin or taking photosensitsing medication

fundingsource.fundingname: National Research and Medical Research Council

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study assesses whether exposure to solar ultraviolet radiation at levels relevant to normal daily activities can suppress the immune response to vaccination in young, healthy adults.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Australian National University Human Research Ethics Committee
